caption:
Kevin Hart met Jeff Bezos at a 2019 Super Bowl party, surrounded by celebrities and business leaders. When Bezos entered, most guests tried to act ‚Äútoo cool,‚Äù avoiding interaction. Hart recognized that attitude as exactly why many people don‚Äôt move ahead-ego and fear of looking eager stop them from learning and connecting. Ignoring that, he approached Bezos with his wife, introduced himself, and said, ‚ÄúHey man, I admire you. I don‚Äôt know much about your world, but I admire what you‚Äôve built.‚Äù He wasn‚Äôt asking for favors, just initiating a genuine connection and showing respect. Later on Joe Rogan‚Äôs podcast, Hart explained that most people never progress because they avoid vulnerability and curiosity. He believes success comes from asking questions and s showing humility, not acting like you already know everything. ‚ÄúEverybody‚Äôs too cool,‚Äù he said, describing how true ambition should be ‚Äúfueled by possibility.‚Äù For Hart, meeting Bezos wasn‚Äôt about celebrity status‚Äîit was a reminder that confidence, humility, and curiosity are the real keys to getting ahead.

This is why it's impossible to tax
billionaires:
now Give
caption:
Billionaires legally avoid paying big taxes by using a few smart tricks. Instead of taking a salary, they get paid in stock options, which means they don‚Äôt get taxed like regular income.

When they need cash, they borrow money using their stock as collateral instead of selling it. Loans don‚Äôt count as income, so they don‚Äôt pay taxes on that money.

Also, if they sell some stock at a loss, they can use that loss to reduce taxes on other stock sales. This way, they can have a lot of money without paying big income taxes every year.

These methods are legal and used by many billionaires to lower their tax bills.

caption:
Elon Musk and the PayPal team beat competitors by inventing a simple yet powerful bank account authentication method that operated like a unique, one-time PIN code. Instead of relying on slow or cumbersome traditional methods (such as faxing voided checks), they decided to generate and send two small random deposits (like $0.12 and $0.35) to a new user‚Äôs bank account. The user would then enter these two amounts back into PayPal‚Äôs site, forming a four-digit ‚Äúpin‚Äù that proved real ownership of the account.

Musk himself described this as a fundamental breakthrough, emphasizing that this process enabled PayPal to authenticate bank accounts securely and at scale without even seeing the user. He noted that no existing U.S. financial systems had a way to reliably authenticate ‚Äúpulling‚Äù money from accounts; this innovation solved it, giving PayPal a safe, user-friendly method that competitors could not easily replicate.

This breakthrough dramatically improved fraud control, slashed the ability of criminals to quickly create fake accounts, and gave PayPal the credibility and user trust it needed to become the leading online payments company.

caption:
The Red Bull Plane Swap was a daring aviation stunt attempted on April 24, 2022, featuring experienced skydivers and pilots Luke Aikins and Andy Farrington, who are cousins and members of the Red Bull Air Force. Their objective was to execute a world-first by swapping planes mid-air. Each flew a modified Cessna 182 aircraft to 14,000 feet before putting them into synchronized nosedives. The planes were equipped with custom airbrake systems and modified autopilot to hold a vertical descent of about 140 mph‚Äîmatching the pilots‚Äô freefall speed. Both pilots jumped out simultaneously, intending to cross paths and enter each other‚Äôs cockpits before regaining control and landing. However, during the stunt, one plane went into an inverted spin, making it impossible for Farrington to reach it safely. Aikins managed to board Farrington‚Äôs plane and land successfully, while Farrington deployed his parachute and landed unharmed. 

The unmanned plane crashed in the Arizona desert, though no one was injured. The Federal Aviation Administration later revealed it had denied Aikins‚Äô exemption request to leave the cockpit mid-flight under regulation FAR 91.105(a). Despite this, Red Bull proceeded with the event, resulting in both pilots having their licenses revoked and fines issued. 

The National Transportation Safety Board determined the crash was caused by the plane exceeding its critical angle of attack, leading to a stall and inverted spin. The stunt, live-streamed on Hulu, became one of Red Bull‚Äôs most talked-about attempts, representing both a triumph in engineering and a reminder of the risks inherent in extreme aviation.

Everybody except Jeff Bezos hated

about it
caption:
Jeff Bezos often talks about ‚Äútwo-way doors‚Äù‚Äîdecisions that are reversible.

You can walk through, try something, and if it doesn‚Äôt work, walk right back out.

Most decisions in business are two-way doors. Yet, companies treat them like one-way doors‚Äîslow, cautious, overly analyzed.

This leads to a bigger problem: they rely too much on past information to make future decisions.

Why is that a mistake?

Because the world changes fast. What worked last year may not work tomorrow. Still, most teams dig into old data, case studies, and past strategies to chart their next move. But if the environment has shifted‚Äîeven slightly‚Äîthat old data can become a trap.

Bezos flipped this on its head at Amazon. He believed in moving fast with reversible decisions. Experiment, learn, adapt. That mindset allowed Amazon to launch bold ideas‚ÄîPrime, AWS, Kindle‚Äîwithout being paralyzed by precedent.

So, don‚Äôt let yesterday‚Äôs success define tomorrow‚Äôs actions. And recognize the doors you can walk back through. Most of them are.

Bill Gates Sr., the father of Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, played a crucial role in helping Howard Schultz buy Starbucks in 1987. At that time, Starbucks was financially struggling and its founders had decided to sell the company for $3.8 million. Howard Schultz, who had left Starbucks to start his own coffee shop but wanted to buy Starbucks back, was given an exclusive 60-day period to raise the money.

During that fundraising, another investor‚Äîan unnamed Seattle ‚Äútitan‚Äù‚Äîoffered a higher bid of $4 million to buy Starbucks, undermining Schultz‚Äôs deal. Desperate, Schultz confided in a young lawyer friend who told him to seek out Bill Gates Sr. at his law firm. When Schultz met Gates Sr., he explained the situation, and Gates Sr. took decisive action by confronting the competing investor. Gates Sr., described as a towering and forceful figure, told the investor to ‚Äústand down‚Äù and not to steal Schultz‚Äôs dream. After this intervention, Schultz secured the necessary support, including an investment from Gates Sr., and successfully purchased Starbucks for $3.8 million.

Schultz credits this moment as pivotal for his life and the growth of Starbucks, describing Bill Gates Sr. as directly responsible for his success and the company‚Äôs development, though Gates Sr. never publicly spoke of his help.

When creating the first popular graphical web browser Mosaic in 1993, which had only 256 colors available, Andreessen chose blue for hyperlinks because it was a ‚Äúnice firm color‚Äù and easy to see. The choice was somewhat arbitrary, as other colors like red, purple, or green could have been used, but blue stood out well on the gray background he preferred to use for reading comfort. This decision was personal and practical rather than based on any formal design standards at the time.

Andreessen also wanted to implement dark mode early on, with white text on black backgrounds, but the screen technology then wasn‚Äôt good enough for that to be readable. So, black text on gray background with blue links became the standard interface. This color scheme gained widespread adoption as Mosaic became the dominant early browser, setting the standard for web interactions that has lasted decades. Essentially, hyperlinks are blue because Marc Andreessen liked blue, and this simple early choice shaped the web‚Äôs visual language.

houses
caption:
Mark Cuban bought a lifetime flight pass on American Airlines called the AAirpass in 1990. He purchased it for $125,000 after selling his first company, MicroSolutions, for $6 million, celebrating his newfound millionaire status. Cuban bought the pass somewhat impulsively while hungover, calling American Airlines to ask if lifetime passes were even real. The AAirpass gave him almost unlimited first-class flights for life, including a companion ticket. He later upgraded the pass and eventually transferred it to his father, and after his father‚Äôs passing, to a friend.

The AAirpass program was launched by American Airlines in the early 1980s, offering unlimited first-class travel for life at a fixed price. The $125,000 Cuban paid back then would be roughly equivalent to $300,000 today when adjusted for inflation. American Airlines stopped selling new lifetime passes in 2022 and ended the program entirely in March 2024.

What led to the first iPhone was years of R&D‚Äîand Steve Jobs‚Äô ultimate decision-making.

While working on a multi-touch tablet, it struck him: instead of a tablet, they could just make it a phone. That idea changed everything. They spent years refining it, and finally launched in 2007.

The rest is history.

And oh‚Äîinertial scrolling and rubber-banding were terms they used to describe the iPhone UI back in the day.
Inertial scrolling was when the list kept moving after your finger lifted, slowing down gradually like real-world momentum.

Rubber-banding was when you scrolled past the top or bottom and the screen bounced back gently, like stretching a rubber band.
